channel.title: Posts on Colin Spear
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Colin Spear

item.title: Doing the work > Preparing for the work
item.description: Links Tyler Cowen and David Perell Anna Gat Music: A Subversive History Agnes Callard on the Ezra Klein Show Me, being oh so witty Motivating questions How do we know when to push and when to rest, both at the micro level (e.g. in daily/weekly subproject level) and at the macro level (e.g. what projects to take on, when to quit a project)? What is the relationship between striving and acceptance?

item.title: On being nice
item.description: My comparative advantage (the craft of being nice :face_with_open_mouth_vomiting::nauseated_face:) It’s not often you see your CFO holding back tears. It’s even rarer when the reason he’s doing so is because you’re being fired. No, I wasn’t part of a mass layoff or a restructuring or a merger or anything like that. I just wasn’t very good at my job. We all knew it and I had already been interviewing at other places.

item.title: Testy testy
item.description: Hypothesize everything Links / Sources / inspirations Karl Popper’s idea that the scientific method is about Conjectures and Refutations. We make a conjecture, then we gather evidence to test the conjecture. Motivating questions What is progress? Truth? How do we evaluate our lives? How do we understand our decisions, make sense of our past and make better decisions going forward? Outline The formal hypothesis test Do a plain language overview, include some charts.

item.title: Taking biproject slowdown seriously
item.description: Taking big project slowdown seriously Links https://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2012/07/why-does-it-take-so-long-build-stuff-these-days/ https://reason.com/2021/03/25/why-does-american-infrastructure-cost-more-and-take-longer-to-build-than-it-used-to/ An evaluation of one (or more) of Patrick Collison’s “Fast” projects compared to something similar today Why might big projects take longer now than in the past? Regulation both good and bad health and safety environment other more alternatives available now than in the past (even if the alternatives aren’t that great) I feel like there’s been a major formalizing of economic, social and political life over the last century that is somehow related to this.

item.title: Is it immoral to be rich?
item.description: Motivation The idea was something I was exposed to and sort of absorbed growing up. I remember having a conversation with some friends who clearly held this view. We were talking about Bill Gates and they seemed to be convinced that he was an evil person which just didn’t square with my ideas about the economic, intellectual and technological advances from home computing (not to mention the philanthropy of the Gates Foundation).

item.title: Randomization inference
item.description: Randomization inference Links Section in Causal Inference, the mixtape Abadie, Athey paper Randomization inference Just want to think a bit about what I’ve been reading about randomization inference It is an alternative, experiment inspired framework for thinking about and performing causal inference Cunningham treats it mostly like a robustness test (from what I can tell) outside of limited contexts, and still maybe in the most appropriate contexts as it’s not super mainstream for example, they say that it’s especially useful for situations in which, instead of working with a random sample of a population, there is good reason to believe you are working with the entire population itself what does this mean for external validity?

item.title: The value of activities with low economic return
item.description: Inspired by an exchange between Rob Henderson and David Perell about the importance of “being able to get rich” as an incentive to draw overeducated people into the internet content production machine1 economy. Links unbuilders The cost of running a restaurant Motivating questions What are some high value add activities / businesses / sectors where economic returns don’t seem to match social benefits? Where is the economic return to business far lower than the social benefit?

item.title: Stoicism vs Sentimentalism
item.description: Stoicism vs Sentimentalism Use Agnes Callard’s On Anger as an argument against rationality. In this view the truly rational thing is to hold a grudge and exact revenge forever and ever, amen. It is the irrational dissolution of anger that allows for peace and resolution Not exactly support for my gotta be irrational to be ethical thesis, but rather the opposite. Anyway, relevant. https://twitter.com/womenpostingws/status/1398786339785433092?s=19

item.title: Change git branch (master to main)
item.description: Here’s another thing I’ve googled enough times to just put it somewhere I know. First, rename your local branch: ❯ git branch -m master main Then you can check that it worked: ❯ git status On branch main Your branch is up to date with 'origin/master'. nothing to commit, working tree clean If you don’t have dependencies that might get screwed up by simply renaming your master branch, you can just navigate to your remote directory and change the name (if you use github, from the repo’s home page, click Settings > Branches and then click the edit button that looks like a little pencil).

item.title: Flask wordcount app
item.description: I made a simple flask app that takes a URL as input and returns a table and chart of the most used words on the site. Built with Flask using a Postgres backend. Uses beautiful soup to scrape and process html from given website. Implements a Redis task queue to handle requests. Uses Angular to poll the back end for completion and to display a word frequency chart using JavaScript and D3.

item.title: Cleaning Vancouver's open business license data
item.description: This is the first post in a series on building an end to end machine learning tool using Vancouver Businesses License data from Vancouver’s Open Data Portal. V0 will be a trained model, served up to a website with a simple front end where aspiring Vancouver business owners can plug in some information about their business and get back a success likelihood score1 that can help them decide if opening their business is a good idea.

item.title: Change your file permissions, baby!
item.description: Knowing how to set file permissions is very useful (for a much more thorough primer than I provied here, see this article). Unfortunately, while this is very easy to do, it is even easier to forget the codes used to do so. So here’s how you do it! The easiest (shortest) way to change permissions is using octal syntax. Octal syntax goes like this: chmod <owner><group><others> filename Where <owner>, <group> and <others> stand for the octal numeral pertaining to that user or group.

item.title: Move and rename all files in a folder
item.description: I wanted to move and rename a bunch of excel files in a folder. This is one way to do it from the command line, copying into a directory in the parent folder. I did it this way to be able to rm -r old_folder after copying my files to the new folder. You could modify it to rename them in place, but I’ve accidentally rm -rfed enough things to get nervous doing it that way.
